tie

ned out of hand, to send a supplie of their owne re-
partition: for w
ch
I am persuaded,
at unles I had
proceeded in suche peremptorie sort, they would ether

at
rather then
e

r

ties

ties

ce

tie

In their late consultation, about
e further
imploiment of their forces abroade, wherof I made

r

solved to passe

ch

a bruite at this p
nt
,

age, he hath taken

e
D. of Parma

as happy, as
e Project is cast, it is thought the
F

Mons
r

r

But there is nothing yet done, nor they doe not

this instant, by a letter brought unto me, from
e
gouverno
r

at

Hig
es
. Whether they doe it, to force him by that

at they thinke it sufficient, to keepe
the towne from
e Enemie, though there should be
but fower in place of
e six, I can not yet under-
stand. But
e gouvernor deteneth two Englishe com-
panies, of
e nomber of those,
at should be sent. And
w
t

tie
to depart w

That

hand both all

But otherwise
e officer of
e Treasurer shall be
willed to w
t
hold their weekely intertenment, un-
till it be perfourmed. For as I will signifie,

at

nt

t

tie

ch

e
states is too weake in very deede for defense
of

Wherupon I have written to
e officer of
e Trea-
surer, to persist continually in w
t
